title: Biden Goes on the Offensive Against Trump
summary: Thousands turn out at Philadelphia rally as former vice president presents himself as best candidate to beat Trump. PHILADELPHIA-Democratic candidate Joe Biden said President Trump inherited a strong U.S. economy and 10 years of growth from former President Obama, just as he inherited much of his wealth from his father.

title: OPEC Considers Two Scenarios to Adjust Oil Production
summary: The group's simulations look at risks of another crude oil glut. JEDDAH, Saudi Arabia-The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies are set to debate at least two scenarios that would increase oil production beyond current levels, according to people familiar with the discussions.

title: Austrian Video Scandal Highlights Concerns Over Nationalist Links to Russia
summary: Chancellor calls new election after his deputy resigns, dealing a blow to far-right movement. Austria's leader called for early elections Saturday after a secretly-recorded video showed his nationalist deputy offering public contracts to a woman he believed to be a Russian oligarch.

title: Resistance to Noncompete Agreements Is a Win for Workers
summary: Several states try to limit contracts that make movement between jobs harder. Quitting a job for a better offer is a time-tested method of securing a pay raise, improved working conditions or both.

title: MTA Vendors Mull Ending Contracts as Authority Seeks 10% Cuts
summary: Firms say the demand forces companies to work for nothing or at a loss. Design and engineering firms have told an industry group they are considering walking away from contracts with New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority after the agency demanded that dozens of vendors cut bills by 10%.

title: Top 'Live-Streamers' Get $50,000 an Hour to Play New Videogames Online
summary: Publishers pay to have celebritylike 'streamers' play their new releases live to build buzz, lift sales; 'It really sold me watching him'. The world's biggest videogame publishers are paying popular gamers tens of thousands of dollars to play their latest releases live over the internet, hoping to break through to buyers in a crowded industry where dominant games like "Fortnite" cast a large shadow.

title: Inside the Effort to Diversify School in New York
summary: Resume Subscription. Principal Eric Sackler spent this spring telling often-skeptical parents why their children would thrive in his Brooklyn middle school, even though it has long had low test scores.

title: 'Dimensionism: Modern Art in the Age of Einstein' Review: A Manifesto to Shake Up the Creative Landscape
summary: An obscure document written in 1936 by an equally obscure Hungarian avant-garde poet influenced artists like Alexander Calder and Jean Arp.. Amherst, Mass.

title: Man Behind Preakness Tradition Eyes the Finish Line
summary: As soon as winning horse is declared, Lawrence Jones paints that jockey's colors on a race-course weather vane. BALTIMORE-Since 1988, Lawrence Jones has been the keeper of a Preakness Stakes tradition. Every year, moments after the race ends, he paints the winning jockey's colors on a horse-and-rider weather vane at the Pimlico Race Course winner's circle.

title: Even Harvard Is Now Teaching Personal Finance
summary: Professor offering financial-literacy workshops aims to make them relevant to students with diverse economic backgrounds. Add this to the Ivy League curricula: basic financial life skills.

title: Colombia Rearrests Ex-Rebel Commander
summary: Prosecutors say they have new evidence to support allegations against the former FARC commander, who is wanted by the U.S. on drug charges. BOGOTÁ-Colombian authorities rearrested a former commander of the FARC rebel group who is wanted by the U.S. on drug charges, just minutes after he was released from jail by a special court order that triggered an institutional crisis and roiled the country's troubled peace process.

summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Machines Built From Living Matter
summary: In a convergence of biology and engineering, scientists are looking to the organic world to create new tools and materials. When materials engineer Angela Belcher submitted her first post-doctoral grant proposal in 1999, one professional reviewer declared it "insane." Dr. Belcher wanted to engineer viruses to "grow" electronic circuits to make batteries. She got the idea while studying for her Ph.D at the University of California at Santa Barbara, where she collected abalone shells on the beach. How, she wondered, did the mollusks make such a strong, lightweight case?

title: For Teens, Romances Where the Couple Never Meets Are Now Normal
summary: A generation that lives online is redefining dating; 'We only met for 20 minutes and that was the first and last time we ever saw each other'. If we're looking for an explanation of why today's teens are having less sex than previous generations, there's this: Many of them spend months or even years dating without ever meeting face to face.

title: Meet the Fixers Pitting States Against Each Other to Win Tax Breaks for New Factories
summary: Resume Subscription. Georgia rolls out a red carpet for them at the Masters Golf Tournament. Kentucky gets them tickets to the Kentucky Derby. Arkansas takes them on a private duck hunt with the governor. Utah recently arranged a private ski trip with an Olympic medalist.

title: The Airline CEO Who Canceled His Salary
summary: Choosing to be paid entirely in stock, Doug Parker wanted to signal he was a different breed of executive and bullish about the long term.. Roughly three months ago, Doug Parker, the chief executive of American Airlines , wrote his company a personal check for $10,000.

title: Brooks Koepka Holds Blowout Lead at PGA Championship
summary: Tiger Woods fails to make the cut a month after Masters victory. FARMINGDALE, N.Y.-The leader at the PGA Championship is turning in a vintage Tiger Woods performance, reminiscent of the days when Woods would completely dominate the rest of the field. Only the leader isn't Woods.
